summary: study shows mast cells may play roles in adaptive and adaptive immunity. mast cells are best known for their role in immunoglobulin E (IgE)-dependent allergic responses. crosslinking of FcRI-bound IgE with multivalent antigen initiates activation of mast cells by promoting the aggregation of FcRI. granules contain vasoactive amines, neutral proteases, proteoglycans and some cytokines and growth factors. the role of mast cells in acute allergic reactions is now widely accepted [4,5,7,8] mast cells have been proposed to play a role in mediating bacterial clearance by releasing cytokines and by killing opsonized bacteria. this suggests that mast cells have a physiological role in modulating host defenses against infectious agents. mast cells appear have effects in the initiation and regulation of innate immunity. over 559 genes were differentially regulated in the stimulated cells. a substantial number of genes were regulated by IgE sensitization alone. some of the most prominent findings are the upregulation of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines. cells were characterized as Mast Cells by flow cytometry as positive for the specific mast cell marker intracellular chymase. positive c-Kit/CD117+ and FcRI+, and by Toluidine blue staining.
